review_title: Probably the most corrupt company I've ever worked for.
pros: Shiny new buildings and free lunches.
cons: They had this dean who was as corrupt as they get and the school pretty much supported him in whatever he did. He'd often remove benefits to anyone he didn't like and was incredibly micro-managing. If the wrong student files a complaint against you, good luck, the school will use you as a scapegoat to protect themselves and terminate you just to protect themselves from losing state funding. They often low-ball salaries on your contracts the day after you've negotiated a higher rate and pretend like you wouldn't notice. The talent level in this place is next to zero. It's just not here.

review_title: CSU is good place to study for upward mobility, but they won't give raises to their union employees
pros: There are programs in place to help students who are not well off. I admire the staff and faculty working towards helping students achieve their education.
cons: In 2020, they furloughed their union staff for a month, and denied SEIU and CWA unionized staff raises for all 3 years of their contracts. In this same year, 2020, the President received a $65,000 bonus. SEIU staff were offered very small bonuses for staying during the 3 years, but these bonuses won't effect our pension in retirement. They won't even buy a nice refrigerator. Our pensions are projected to be lower due to the lack of a pay raise for these 3 years. CSU's management recently wanted to offer a 6 year contract to their faculty in which the amount of raise would be 0.50% the first year and 0.25% the following 5 years. A fact finder found that the university is doing financially very well right now. There is no justification for not giving faculty and union staff reasonable raises. It's demoralizing.

job_title: Student IT Technician in Cleveland, OH
pros: I was a student technician in CSU's IS&T Department and it was the best job I could have as a student.  Hours were flexible, the pay was OK, and the department even paid for training/certifications.  My supervisors were great and very supporting to the student technicians.  Many of the students would find an internship or co-op for a semester or so, and many of them came back to IS&T afterwards because most of us had a great relationship with our supervisors.  I learned so much from this job and still use many of the skills I learned in IS&T today.
cons: While there are smart and polite people in this department, a handful of the senior managers are complete morons who are disconnected from the rest of the department.  Recently, they (sort of) fixed this and juggled them around to different areas.  In addition, my supervisors' boss threatened to get rid of all the student workers at least once a year.  Good luck supporting all faculty and staff computing equipment when your student workers (about 20 technicians) that do your heavy-lifting and dirty work are gone.

review_title: Perspective of a PhD Graduate Student
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cleveland, OH
pros: Good university to attend if you are interested in pursuing a future in Clinical Chemistry. Has a variety of faculty members doing all different kinds of research from organic synthesis to many different types of clinical research and testing.  As a Teacher Assistant, you teach at least 2 laboratories each week throughout  each semester and are required to teach  1 session over the summer. The university will cover the cost of the 9 credit hours of course work/research required for each semester as a graduate student. Each credit hour is about 450$ so this adds up to about 4000$ of financial aid a semester. In addition, a stipend is given to graduate students who are also TA's. The living stipend is about 21,000 a year after tax.
cons: You have to pay for healthcare out of pocket - will cost you about 1800$/year if you are single, healthy individual. Higher level TA assignments generally require more time than others (ex. organic chemistry, analytical chemistry, instrumental analysis plus a few others). Only compensated for 20 hours a week even though some assignments will require much more time than this. More so, the university  could use some upgrades on analytical instruments as to some of them are more than 15 to 20 years old.

review_title: If you are looking for professional growth, come work at Cleveland State!
pros: My manager gives me the freedom to do my job and looks out for me, assuring that I don't run afoul of any other departments.  My co-workers care about our students and share my attitude that they are not an interruption of our work, but that they are the reason for it.  In our office, everyone from support staff to management is treated with respect and given more than enough opportunity for professional growth, including academic and continuing education courses, attendance at conferences and on campus workshops.  Overall, the University has finally adopted a more customer service centric attitude about our students, one that our department has always had.
cons: Our VP is knowledgeable about our department's mission and believes that our work is important, but not all VP's may feel that way.  Work outside of higher education may pay more, but the level of job satisfaction here more than compensates for monetary compensation.

review_title: Great way to pay for partial education, good work environment
pros: Good to work with fellow students as a graduate assistant. Some assistantships are undeserved, which is painful to watch. Tuition reimbursement is fantastic, bi-weekly stipend is small but helps (you'll still need to take out student loans). The best pro is that it provides some work experience and income while allowing you to do well in grad school. The balance couldn't be better, especially if you work for someone who allows you to make your own schedule.
cons: Some students at CSU (Urban College) really shouldn't be there, particularly at the post-graduate level. They may use the excuse of a learning disability but at some point higher education may not be for you. It is recommended that you have an above average intelligence level, but this just does not happen there. There are some well-deserved students. Team up with them and your experience will be just fine.

pros: There are some really great, dedicated employees. Opportunities to use tuition assistance for faculty and staff for both credit courses as well as continuing education  are excellent.
cons: Anyone with an entrpreneurial spirit, and great ideas will find themselves drowning in bureacracy and mediocrity. The institution is so slow to change. All too often people who are underqualified, under motivated, and not working very hard are in positions of power, blocking the ideas and forward progress of more capable people below them.

pros: They care about you and your studies--if you tell them you have a midterm and need some time off to prepare, they're more than happy to accommodate. In general, they will argue FOR you and argue that you should take time off or relax or work a bit slower. Very understanding and good environment to work in because it makes you want to work harder overall. Culture is great, inclusive, and caring. I have been asked for advice and thoughts as an LGBT worker before and it was great to be heard about what CSU should be doing to be welcoming to students.
cons: Honestly, I don't have many. Sometimes CSU can have issues with upper management not understanding the intricacies of the direct work, but that's every job.

review_title: Student jobs are usually very flexible and can pay well.
pros: Very flexible schedule, decent pay, good hours, treated very well for the most part. As far as student jobs go, working for the University allows you the best balance of free time and pay, as well as being treated well.
cons: Some full time employees condescend you, limited hours, no full time opportunity for students since ACA. Also, even as a student you will be forced to contribute to the OPERS retirement system, a perk if your going into public service since you will already have service credits, otherwise, you can file a form to get your money back.

pros: Tuition benefit, nice people, slow pace, location
cons: Politics - current preseident appoints people to jobs without going through the usual process while H.R. and legal advisors insist that everyone else go through the process. Decisions are often made based on politics and personalities. Funds are somehow available for pet projects and not available for things that need to be done to change the culture of the organization. Career development is not done by managers. While slow pace is nice for stress levels, it isn't great when you actually want to get things done. Too much hurry up and wait attitude.

review_title: The food was great the people were nice and the atmosphere was just right.
pros: Great place to work if you like getting payed less to do a goood job.
cons: The pay rate is lousy .

review_title: Administration Gets in the way of learning
job_title: Executive Learning Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: The people that you work directly under are typcially professors with years of experience teaching students. And they have bucketloads of knowledge and skills they can teach you. Being able to work in the same place that you attend school is a plus for those without easy access to transportation.
cons: Colleges move at the same speed as the government, which is to say barely moves at all. Projects will be delayed, necessary equipment will take months to be approved, systems are overly complicated, and restrictions are placed everywhere if you want to make the slightest changes.

pros: I had the ability to implement ideas and supervise a small team. I gained business development experience and attended industry conferences. I was able to attend any training seminars within the university that I desired. The health care, retirement and vacation benefits are generous. The compensation was low for higher education.
cons: Mid-level employees and managers are required to join a union. The union and HR make it difficult for high-performers to be promoted. Many unproductive employees are able to stay in their positions without repercussions.

review_title: Customer Service Rep. at CSU Recreation Center
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Cleveland, OH
pros: As a student attending the university it is very convenient to work there in regards to its downtown location.  The Recreation Center just recently agreed to give all part time positions a 30 cent raise. Shifts during the week are 3 hours long to easily fit between your classes compared to 5 hour shifts on the weekend.  Its really easy to swap shifts with other co workers if you want to double up shifts during the day or take the day off completely.
cons: Parking can be extremely difficult.  Street parking is only free on weekends and after 6 during week days. If you want to work here its important to have people skills.  Overall, it is typically a low stress job; however, it can become highly stressful when guests become injured or if there are alterations on the basketball courts. Some of the patrons that enter the place can be rude and will try to sneak into the facility without paying.  When confronting them you have to be willing to be yelled at. Its the nature of customer service to diffuse these conflicts and any other arguments that should arise.

pros: The energetic atmosphere for learning is everywhere.  There is synergy on this campus.  I leaned so very much. Conversations are well rounded and the work ethic is excellent. I loved working in the Black Studies Program and Howard A. Mims Cultural Arts Center as I earned my Bachelor's degree from the School of Urban Studiers in Nonprofit Administrations.
cons: Red tape and paper work which occurs in most major institutions.  Not a complaint, but an observation.

pros: The interaction with your higher officials and fellow interns is what i love here. The work assigned to me is nicely organized and well explained. It becomes real easy that way.
cons: Pay for the intern is pretty, even though there is nice work atmosphere and the end of the month you would be dissapointed by the pay for the work you have put in.

pros: Flexible work hours and we have good faculty employees. This is the perfect job for a full time student that is taking classes at the same time. We are allowed to work on homework at the job (obviously not when we are doing a task).
cons: Low pay. Other departments offer student works $10 or even $12 an hour! We just get $8.50 an hour

review_title: Great place for Students to Work
pros: The student jobs at Cleveland State really work around a full-time student´s busy schedule, which is great! I get to save for college and  I also get good job experience, and feel like I am being respected as both a student and a worker.
cons: Sometimes the job can get a little demanding, but usually it is nothing that can´t be handled by putting in some extra effort.

job_title: College Associate Lecturer in Cleveland, OH
pros: Great people to work with. Very diverse environment. Urban/downtown location. Committed t0 student success. Wonderful students and the administrative staff are great.
cons: Employees pay for parking. Can sometime be a little hectic. Is sometimes hard to find a parking place. Cleveland is cold in the winter.

pros: Awesome to work alongside staff and get experience teaching courses.
cons: There was an issue where we weren't sure we would get our stipend this year. Fortunately that was solved and students are able to work 10 hours maximum for a stipend. This honestly isn't a con when you factor in that we are getting a masters degree for free and working alongside intelligent and inspiring professors.

review_title: Great work environment in my office.
pros: The group of people I worked with were the best. With the challenges they face and the understaffed office, they still accomplished amazing things.
cons: Dealing with school budgets and decisions that are made in different departments that affect you.

pros: Benefits, schedule flexibility, nice people, location.

pros: I love working with students at Cleveland State. The atmosphere of downtown Cleveland also makes Cleveland State an exciting place to work with the diversity of people, food, and entertainment.
cons: One of the cons is that the pay is not comparable to pay at other institutions. Another con is unrealistic expectations placed on employees when staff is reduced.

review_title: Great place and great people in a great city of champs

cons: There is so little about this place that would give it any cons. If i did have to say anything it would be the traffic.

pros: Public employee pension is one of the best in the country
cons: The university is perpetually challenged by finances -- cuts from the state hamper the budget and ability to bring the best curriculum.

pros: Working climate is good. Employer take care about their workers very properly. It is good to work with the college which improves your skills like communication, positive attitude.
